awd_titl_txt: Conference: Annual Rural STEM Learning Summit
awd_abstract_narration:
Rural communities often lack access to informal learning opportunities. The Rural STEM Learning Summit will promote collaboration and support for rural STEM educators and administrators, professionals, and organizations. Research demonstrates the strengths of rural social enterprises, regional networks, and extended proximity in catalyzing innovation and providing opportunities to overcome these unique challenges. However, rural STEM initiatives face common barriers, such as physical distance, lack of infrastructure, limited individual capacity and stretched resources in developing and maintaining STEM ecosystems. The conference will provide a critical opportunity for enhancing knowledge around innovation in these areas and sharing lessons learned with and advancing collaboration. The focus will be on collective impact, rural empowerment, and successful rural STEM programs. Topics will include research and evaluation, arts integration, partnerships, working with under-resourced populations, and building rural STEM identity. 

The conference will use a variety of formats, including keynotes, brief ("flash") talks presenting quick overviews of programs and ideas, hosted workshops providing ready-made activities and resources, facilitated workshops led by experts, project directors and researchers, and informal opportunities to meet those with common interests. The conference will be structured as a hybrid format with in-person and digital options to support participation. The conference will engage registrants in facilitated discussions aimed at grouping participants around common interests. These cohorts will navigate the conference as a team and collaborate on developing a shared practice/product that can be tested locally and shared more broadly. By engaging a wide variety of rural stakeholders, federal and state governmental institutions, perspectives, viewpoints, and regions, the conference will offer a distinct opportunity for promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion. The conference will host follow-up sessions that will foster continuing collaboration and build momentum for an annual rural STEM education conference. 

This conference is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which supports projects that: (a) contribute to research and practice that considers informal STEM learning's role in equity and belonging in STEM; (b) promote personal and educational success in STEM; (c) advance public engagement in scientific discovery; (d) foster interest in STEM careers; (e) create and enhance the theoretical and empirical foundations for effective informal STEM learning; (f) improve community vibrancy; and/or (g) enhance science communication and the public's engagement in and understanding of STEM and STEM processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The second annual National Rural STEM Summit engaged formal and informal rural educators, administrators, professionals, and organizations in cross-community, cross-sector conversations to share effective STEM teaching and engagement models across different settings. The Summit was held June 5-7, 2024, at the Westin La Paloma Resort and Spa in Tucson, Arizona. Attendees included 140 ​participants and 41 presenters and speakers from the education, nonprofit, private, and government sectors. 

For many participants, learning about new STEM activities was a major motivation for attending. A post-event survey found that most attendees (94%) have integrated or plan on engaging preK-12 STEM learners with activities introduced at the event. Activities ranged from Minecraft in Education and coding projects, turn-key engagement tools, NASA-funded STEM programs, and insights into current research on leadership in STEM Learning, among others. Attendees also reported learning the importance of developing lesson plans around local issues, enhancing networking and collaboration, changing approaches and ways of thinking, and developing capacity in community education and educators.

One respondent noted, “[I] Really appreciated the built-in time to interact and learn with others, not just during the sessions. Generous time for interactions. Very glad it was opened up to national attendance as it was helpful to hear from others in other states.”

Beyond individual learning, the Summit has led to exciting new collaborations. For example, a group of Summit attendees came together to develop an NSF STEM Teacher Corps Pilot Program proposal. The Teacher Corp program is elevating the STEM teaching profession by supporting regional alliances dedicated to recognizing outstanding STEM teachers in our Nation’s classrooms, elevating their public profile, and creating rewarding career paths to which all STEM teachers can aspire. 

Following the Summit, the STEM Learning Ecosystem Community of Practice (SLECoP) recognized the need to promote and recognize rural STEM achievements more intentionally. During their 2024 International Convening in October 2024, SLECoP will highlight the Rural STEM Summit and lessons learned. In addition, the organization's communication and leadership teams are posting regular rural-focused blog posts, integrating rural opportunities into their marketing plan, and supporting sustained collaboration with rural STEM educators and practitioners.

In response to several breakout sessions, the Superintendent and Director of Federal Programs from the Chinle Unified School District (the Navajo Nation's largest district) brought together thought partners who met at the Summit to develop a K12 STEM growth plan. Two months after the Summit, the first in a series of co-developed collaborative projects took place with 320 teachers and 85 support staff. These projects are benefiting the District's 3,100+ students. 

Requests for engagement by rural school districts represented at the Summit to the University of Arizona School of Mining and Mineral Resources K12 outreach team increased by 30%. Similarly, 11 STEM organizations requested additional information on the role of out-of-school-time STEM learning impacts in response to Dr. Holly Miller's Out of Schooltime (OST) Learning to Re-Engage Student STEM Interests presentation. Dr. Mills is the Advisor for the Afterschool and Summer Learning Fellow in the Institute of Education Sciences at the U.S. Department Of Education. The presentation available is on the Summit website. 

A pre-conference workshop reintroduced the "Project Archaeology" curriculum following a hiatus of almost a decade. The workshop showcased a new module based on Tohono O’odham traditional pit houses created in collaboration with Tohono O’odham elders and National Park Service Archeologists. Tohono O’odham is an Indigenous nation near Tucson, AZ. Participants included district-level curriculum directors or specialists, National and State Park interpretive rangers, and K12 educators. Following conversations with attendees, the President of the Arizona Library Association invited the Project Archaeology state coordinator to host workshops at libraries across the state.

Future Plans

Due to the success of the Project Archaeology workshop, future Summits will include a more robust selection of pre-conference workshops. This addition will allow for focused, deep-dive opportunities. Attendees expressed interest in workshops around Strategic Doing, Environmental Education, AI in the classroom, Cybersecurity, STEM Competitions, and Authentic Research in the classroom and out-of-school-time venues. In addition, participant feedback has provided input into breakout session formatting. The 2025 Summit will include sector-specific sessions, allowing participants to explore resources across the learning ecosystem that align with their interests.

The 2023 and 2024 Summits focused on and included a national audience. Attendee demographic analysis indicates that participants were predominantly from Arizona and Western US states (87% in 2024). Taking cues from the evaluation and post-attendee feedback, the 2025 Summit will shift to focus on Western states to support regional STEM learning opportunities and partners that share a similar culture. Collaborators from outside this region will be welcome to attend. As noted by one 2024 out-of-state participant, this Summit is a model for implementing a similar convening in their home state, and the experience was exceptional.
